elements.label: The Debate of Seven Cups
elements.description: 'Time is a pure flame, and we live by an invisible sun within us.'

elements.label: De Ratio Quercuum
elements.description: 'In Persia taxus baccata is called sorkdhar, which is 'the red tree'. There they had long understood the Grail-Root. In later times, the Great King of Pontus had bee-hives set in the branches of the oldest of the female trees. The berries open the door to death but the honey of their flowers opens a different door entirely. This was not his mithridate but one who has suckled at the Great Yew fears poison no longer. Perhaps they should...'

elements.label: Sunset Diaries (1)
elements.description: In 1959, Christopher Illopoly uncovered a truth which changed everything for him. That, he writes, is why he began to keep these diaries.

elements.label: Travelling at Night (1)
elements.description: Volume 1 of the annotated dream-journals of Christopher Illopoly, sometimes called 'the only readable occultist': literate, entertaining, bewildering.

elements.label: Travelling at Night (2)
elements.description: Volume 2 of the annotated dream-journals of Christopher Illopoly, sometimes called 'the only readable occultist': literate, entertaining, bewildering.

elements.label: The Tripled Heart
elements.description: 'Morning, noon, evening. These are not yet moonlight.'

elements.label: The Turquoise Hand
elements.description: A calligraphic manual of Ramsund which employs as exemplar-text Farid ud-Din's 'Conference of the Birds'. Its commentary, illustrations and interleavings carry revelations never intended in the original.
